comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
I think there is something unusual about the face of the child in this image.

Going through to the persistent URL and zooming in on the face, the face then appears to be covered in fine hairs which would be unusual for a child of this age - around 2 years old.

Otherwise, maybe it is fine scratching on the image, but it seems to have only affected the face portion.  Maybe it is due to the age of the plate.

comment._content: This child may have a slight hare-lip. What's really scary if it's dated about 1904, it's probably my grandfather.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: I echo the sentiments of all those who have commented on this photograph ... that one arm of the baby is larger ... that it looks like the child is being held from behind ... and that the baby's face is "unusual". My hit is that this is a composite of two or more images -- similar (not exact) to other images posted from this series. I have enlarged portions of two images in this series, and refer to those enlargements as "work-prints". "Work-print A" is an enlargement from: "Three people (and a baby) in a garden" by Phillips And "Work-print B" is an enlargement from: "Portrait of a seated woman in Edwardian dress, with baby" by Phillips "Work-Print A" by Phillips                             "Work-Print B" by Phillips         1. I speculate that a woman (wearing a dark dress) was seated and holding the baby -- and her left arm and hand was resting on top of the baby's ... thus it was kept in the final image (the opposite of how it was posed in this photo). 2. The outline of a seated woman, similar to those in the series (with hat), can be seen in the final image (almost as a black "shadow). 3. To my eye, in the final print (below), the "vertical grey-white stripe" at the left of the photo is the arm of one of the chairs (from either work-print) -- while the "image" of the cane/wicker chair has been added. In fact part of the image of the cane/wicker chair appears to have been superimposed over the other chair. (Also see this chair, and same baby, with a different background.) 4. There is a fragment of the baby's hat (seen in Work-Print A) that remains in the final photo. (It is possible that this is a fragment of a cuff as shown in this photo.) 5. The pattern of the fence in the background of both work-prints can be seen in the final photo. 6. The baby's face may have been manipulated (transplanted) from another image, and like the rest of the photo is heavily retouched. "Small child wearing smocked dress" by Phillips There are, of course, dozens of reasons why an isolated photograph of this baby could be desired. I doubt anyone involved ever imagined that someone a hundred. years in the future would be guessing about this ;-)

comment.author: 61361160@N00
comment._content: This photograph is featured in the fabulously fun Indicommons.org post Kitten, Baby, Sunset, Flower! Play with us in the Flickr Commons group!
